Text saved: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games, a series of books about a deadly competition, comes from Suzanne Collins’ love of ancient Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was about Theseus, a brave hero who fought a monster called the Minotaur, which was half man and half bull. In that story the city of Athens, a powerful Greek city, is ruled by Crete. Crete’s king Minos forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls each year as punishment, and the youths are placed in a labyrinth where the Minotaur lives and eats them. However, Theseus volunteers, defeats the Minotaur and frees the people. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen, the main heroine of the Hunger Games, as a modern version of Theseus because she also challenges a cruel system.

When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was the tale of Theseus and the Minotaur. In that story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians fight back. One of the youths, Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
